verses.text: Now the Philistines gathered together their armies to battle, and were gathered together \add at\add* Shochoh, which \add belongeth\add* to Judah, and pitched between Shochoh and Azekah, in Ephes-dammim.
And Saul and the men of Israel were gathered together, and pitched by the valley of Elah, and set the battle in array against the Philistines.
And the Philistines stood on a mountain on the one side, and Israel stood on a mountain on the other side: and \add there was\add* a valley between them.
And there went out a champion out of the camp of the Philistines, named Goliath, of Gath, whose height \add was\add* six cubits and a span.
And \add he had\add* a helmet of brass upon his head, and he \add was\add* armed with a coat of mail; and the weight of the coat \add was\add* five thousand shekels \add of\add* brass.
And \add he had\add* greaves of brass upon his legs, and a target of brass between his shoulders.
And the staff of his spear \add was\add* like a weaver’s beam; and his spear’s head \add weighed\add* six hundred shekels \add of\add* iron: and one bearing a shield went before him.

And he stood and cried unto the armies of Israel, and said unto them, Why are ye come out to set \add your\add* battle in array? \add am\add* not I a Philistine, and you servants to Saul? choose you a man for you, and let him come down to me.
If he be able to fight with me, and \add to\add* kill me, then will we be your servants: but if I prevail against him, and kill him, then shall ye be our servants, and serve us.
And the Philistine said, I defy the armies of Israel this day; give me a man, that we may fight together.
When Saul and all Israel heard those words of the Philistine, they were dismayed, and greatly afraid.
Now David \add was\add* the son of that Ephrathite of Beth-lehem-judah, whose name \add was\add* Jesse; and he had eight sons: and the man went among men \add for\add* an old man in the days of Saul.

And the three eldest sons of Jesse went \add and\add* followed Saul to the battle: and the names of his three sons that went to the battle \add were\add* Eliab the firstborn, and next unto him Abinadab, and the third Shammah.
And David \add was\add* the youngest: and the three eldest followed Saul.
But David went and returned from Saul to feed his father’s sheep \add at\add* Beth-lehem.
And the Philistine drew near morning and evening, and presented himself forty days.
And Jesse said unto David his son, Take now for thy brethren an ephah of this parched \add corn\add*, and these ten loaves, and run \add to\add* the camp to thy brethren;
and carry these ten cheeses unto the captain of \add their\add* thousand, and look how thy brethren fare, and take their pledge.
Now Saul, and they, and all the men of Israel, \add were\add* in the valley of Elah, fighting with the Philistines.

And David rose up early in the morning, and left the sheep with a keeper, and took, and went, as Jesse had commanded him; and he came to the trench, as the host was going forth to the fight, and shouted for the battle.
For Israel and the Philistines had put \add the battle\add* in array, army against army.
And David left his carriage in the hand of the keeper of the carriage, and ran \add into\add* the army, and came and saluted his brethren.

And as he talked with them, behold, there came up the champion, the Philistine of Gath, Goliath by name, out of the armies of the Philistines, and spake according to the same words: and David heard \add them\add*.
And all the men of Israel, when they saw the man, fled from him, and were sore afraid.

And the men of Israel said, Have ye seen this man that is come up? surely to defy Israel is he come up: and it shall be, \add that\add* the man who killeth him, the king will enrich him \add with\add* great riches, and will give him his daughter, and make his father’s house free in Israel.

And David spake to the men that stood by him, saying, What shall be done to the man that killeth this Philistine, and taketh away the reproach from Israel? for who \add is\add* this uncircumcised Philistine, that he should defy the armies of the living God?
And the people answered him after this manner, saying, So shall it be done to the man that killeth him.

And Eliab his eldest brother heard when he spake unto the men; and Eliab’s anger was kindled against David, and he said, Why camest thou down hither? and with whom hast thou left those few sheep in the wilderness? I know thy pride, and the naughtiness of thine heart; for thou art come down that \add thou\add* mightest see the battle.
And David said, What have I now done? \add Is there\add* not a cause?
And he turned from him towards another, and spake after the same manner: and the people answered him again after the former manner.
And when the words were heard which David spake, they rehearsed \add them\add* before Saul: and he sent for him.
And David said to Saul, Let no man’s heart fail because of him; thy servant will go and fight with this Philistine.
And Saul said to David, Thou art not able to go against this Philistine to fight with him: for thou \add art but\add* a youth, and he a man of war from his youth.
And David said unto Saul, Thy servant kept his father’s sheep, and there came a lion and a bear, and took a lamb out of the flock:
and I went out after him, and smote him, and delivered \add it\add* out of his mouth: and when he arose against me, I caught \add him\add* by his beard, and smote him, and slew him.
Thy servant slew both the lion and the bear: and this uncircumcised Philistine shall be as one of them, seeing he hath defied the armies of the living God.

David said moreover, The \sc Lord\sc* that delivered me out of the paw of the lion, and out of the paw of the bear, he will deliver me out of the hand of this Philistine. And Saul said unto David, Go, and the \sc Lord\sc* be with thee.
And Saul armed David with his armour, and he put a helmet of brass upon his head; also he armed him with a coat \add of mail\add*.

And David girded his sword upon his armour, and he assayed to go; for he had not proved \add it\add*. And David said unto Saul, I cannot go with these; for I have not proved \add them\add*. And David put them off him.

And he took his staff in his hand, and chose him five smooth stones out of the brook, and put them in a shepherd’s bag which he had, even in a scrip; and his sling \add was\add* in his hand: and he drew near to the Philistine.
And the Philistine came on and drew near unto David; and the man that bare the shield \add went\add* before him.
And when the Philistine looked about, and saw David, he disdained him: for he was \add but\add* a youth, and ruddy, and of a fair countenance.
And the Philistine said unto David, \add Am\add* I a dog, that thou comest to me with staves? And the Philistine cursed David by his gods.
And the Philistine said to David, Come to me, and I will give thy flesh unto the fowls of the air, and to the beasts of the field.

Then said David to the Philistine, Thou comest to me with a sword, and with a spear, and with a shield: but I come to thee in the name of the \sc Lord\sc* of hosts, the God of the armies of Israel, whom thou hast defied.

This day will the \sc Lord\sc* deliver thee into mine hand; and I will smite thee, and take thine head from thee; and I will give the carcases of the host of the Philistines this day unto the fowls of the air, and to the wild beasts of the earth; that all the earth may know that there is a God in Israel.
And all this assembly shall know that the \sc Lord\sc* saveth not with sword and spear: for the battle \add is\add* the \sc Lord’s\sc*, and he will give you into our hands.
And it came to pass, when the Philistine arose, and came and drew nigh to meet David, that David hasted, and ran \add toward\add* the army to meet the Philistine.

And David put his hand in \add his\add* bag, and took thence a stone, and slang \add it\add*, and smote the Philistine in his forehead, that the stone sunk into his forehead; and he fell upon his face to the earth.
So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with a stone, and smote the Philistine, and slew him; but \add there was\add* no sword in the hand of David.

Therefore David ran, and stood upon the Philistine, and took his sword, and drew it out of the sheath thereof, and slew him, and cut off his head therewith. And when the Philistines saw their champion was dead, they fled.

And the men of Israel and of Judah arose, and shouted, and pursued the Philistines, until thou come \add to\add* the valley, and to the gates of Ekron. And the wounded of the Philistines fell down by the way to Shaaraim, even unto Gath, and unto Ekron.
And the children of Israel returned from chasing after the Philistines, and they spoiled their tents.
And David took the head of the Philistine, and brought it \add to\add* Jerusalem; but he put his armour in his tent.

And when Saul saw David go forth against the Philistine, he said unto Abner, the captain of the host, Abner, whose son \add is\add* this youth? And Abner said, \add As\add* thy soul liveth, O king, I cannot tell.
And the king said, Inquire thou whose son the stripling \add is\add*.
And as David returned from the slaughter of the Philistine, Abner took him, and brought him before Saul with the head of the Philistine in his hand.
And Saul said to him, Whose son \add art\add* thou, \add thou\add* young man? And David answered, \add I am\add* the son of thy servant Jesse the Beth-lehemite.
